bose_einstein_integrals¶

Integrals over the Bose-Einstein distribution.

Table of Methods

F1(a, b[, epsrel]) Definite integral of x/[(exp(x) - 1)].
F0(a, b[, epsrel]) Definite integral of 1/[(exp(x) - 1)].
F_inv(a, b[, tol]) Definite integral of (1/x)/(exp(x) - 1).
F_inv_3(a, b[, tol]) Definite integral of (1/x**3)/(exp(x) - 1).
F_inv_5(a, b[, tol]) Definite integral of (1/x**5)/(exp(x) - 1).
F_log(a, b[, tol]) Definite integral of log(x)/(exp(x) - 1).
F_x_log(a, b[, tol]) Definite integral of x log(x)/(exp(x) - 1).
F_log_a(lowlim, a[, tol]) Integral of log(x+a)/(exp(x) - 1) from lowlim to infinity.
F_x_log_a(lowlim, a[, tol]) Integral of x log (x+a)/(exp(x) - 1) from lowlim to infinity.

Methods¶

darkhistory.electrons.ics.bose_einstein_integrals.F1(a, b, epsrel=0)¶

Definite integral of x/[(exp(x) - 1)].

Parameters:
  • a (ndarray) – Lower limit of integration. Can be either 1D or 2D.
  • b (ndarray) – Upper limit of integration. Can be either 1D or 2D.
  • err (float) – Error associated with series expansion. If zero, then the error is not computed.
Returns:

The resulting integral.
Return type:

float

Note

For a or b > 0.01, the exact analytic expression is used, whereas below that we use a series expansion. This avoids numerical errors due to computation of log(1 - exp(-x)) and likewise in the spence function. Note that scipy.special.spence can only take float64 numbers, so downcasting is necessary for 0.01 < x < 3.

darkhistory.electrons.ics.bose_einstein_integrals.F0(a, b, epsrel=0)¶

Definite integral of 1/[(exp(x) - 1)].

Parameters:
  • a (ndarray) – Lower limit of integration. Can be either 1D or 2D.
  • b (ndarray) – Upper limit of integration. Can be either 1D or 2D.
  • err (float) – Error associated with series expansion. If zero, then the error is not computed.
Returns:

The resulting integral.
Return type:

float
darkhistory.electrons.ics.bose_einstein_integrals.F_inv(a, b, tol=1e-10)¶

Definite integral of (1/x)/(exp(x) - 1).

Parameters:
  • a (ndarray) – Lower limit of integration.
  • b (ndarray) – Upper limit of integration.
  • tol (float) – The relative tolerance to be reached.
Returns:

The resulting integral.
Return type:

float
